facts.text: Sales Tax Officer, 2nd Circle, Quilon, assessed appellant to sales tax on net assessable turnover of Rs. 7,54,144-8-4 for year 1951-52.

facts.text: Assessment year is 1951-52 from 1st April 1951 to 31st March 1952.

facts.text: Appellant is a registered manufacturer of coconut oil and cake with certificate of registration in Form VI under r.20 of Travancore-Cochin General Sales Tax Rules, 1950.

facts.text: Appellant's business: purchase of copra, manufacture of coconut oil and cake, sale inside Travancore-Cochin and oil outside the State.

anchor.surface_text: General Sales Tax Rules, 1950. The business of the appellant for the purposes of this appeal companysisted in the purchase of companyra, manufacture of companyoanut oil and cake and sale of the same to parties inside the State of Travancore- Cochin

facts.text: In 1951-52, appellant purchased copra of value Rs. 7,16,048-1-4.

anchor.surface_text: Rs. 7,16,048-1-4 and after manufacturing oil therefrom in his oil mills he sold the oil partly in the State and partly outside the State and the cake entirely within the State., The total value

anchor.surface_text: the State and the cake entirely within the State., The total value of the oil sold was Rs. 6,76,719-0-11 out of which the sales outside the State were of the value of Rs. 3,67,816-10-1 and the value

facts.text: Value of cake sold in State: Rs. 67,155-15-5.

anchor.surface_text: Rs. 3,67,816-10-1 and the value of the cake sold in the State was Rs. 67,155-155. The total gross turnover of the appellant was thus Rs. 14,59,923-1-8 and he claimed to deduct therefrom

facts.text: Appellant's total gross turnover: Rs. 14,59,923-1-8.

anchor.surface_text: Rs. 67,155-155. The total gross turnover of the appellant was thus Rs. 14,59,923-1-8 and he claimed to deduct therefrom the whole of the purchase price of the companyra under r. 7  1   k  read

facts.text: Appellant claimed net turnover Rs. 7,43,875-0-4 after deducting copra purchase price, then further deduct Rs. 3,67,816-10-1 for inter-State sales, arriving at Rs. 3,76,058-6-3.

anchor.surface_text: the whole of the purchase price of the companyra under r. 7  1   k  read with r. 20. The net turnover according to him was therefore only Rs. 7,43,875-0-4 and he claimed to deduct out of this a further sum of Rs. 3,67,816- 10-1 being the sale price of oil in inter-State transactions which companyld number be taxed under Art. 286 of the Constitution, thus showing a net assessable turnover of only Rs. 3,76 058-6-3.

facts.text: Sales Tax Officer fixed net assessable turnover at Rs. 7,54,144-8-4.

anchor.surface_text: The Sales Tax Officer, 2nd Circle, Quilon, however fixed the net assessable turnover of the appellant at Rs. 7,54,144-8-4. He took the purchase value of the companyra at Rs. 7,16,048-1-4 but

facts.text: STO added Rs. 3,08,902-6-10 (oil inside State) and Rs. 67,155-15-5 (cake), excluded inter-State oil sales Rs. 3,67,816-10-1.

anchor.surface_text: Rs. 7,54,144-8-4. He took the purchase value of the companyra at Rs. 7,16,048-1-4 but added thereto Rs. 3,08,902-6-10 and Rs. 67,155-15-5 being the respective values of the oil and the cake sold inside the State, excluding the sale price of inter-State sales of oil, namely, Rs. 3,67,816-10-1, from such companyputation.

facts.text: STO deducted copra value corresponding to oil sold inside State: Rs. 3,35,216-0-0.

anchor.surface_text: Having thus excluded the sale price of inter-State sales of oil, he deducted only the value of the companyra companyresponding to the oil sold inside the State namely, Rs. 3,35,216-0-0, as against the sum of Rs.7,16,048-1-4 deducted by the appellant.

facts.text: STO added price of gum sold: Rs. 3,385-0-3; deducted sales tax collected: Rs. 6,130-15-6.

anchor.surface_text: He added a sum of Rs. 3,385-0-3 being the price of gum sold by the appellant and deducted a further sum of Rs. 6,130-15-6 being the sales tax companylected by him. He thus arrived at the net assessable turnover of Rs. 7,54,144-8-4 and assessed the appellant for sales tax on the same.

facts.text: Appellant appealed to Assistant Sales Tax Commissioner in S.T.A. No. 1480 of 1953-54, dismissed on May 10, 1954.

facts.text: Petition to Government dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: who dismissed the same by his order dated May 10, 1954. A further petition to the Government for redress met with the same fate and the appellant thereupon filed the petition in the High Court of Travancore. Cochin

facts.text: Appellant contends entitled to deduct entire copra purchase price Rs. 7,16,048-1-4 from total oil sales value.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companytends that in the calculation of such net turnover he is entitled to include the total value of the oil sold by him, viz., Rs. 6,76,719-0-11, irrespective of the fact whether these sales were effected inside the State or outside the State and deduct therefrom the total value of companyra purchased by him from which the whole quantity of oil sold by him was manufactured, viz., Rs. 7,16,048-1-4.

facts.text: Respondent contends no deduction for copra allocated to inter-State oil sales.

anchor.surface_text: The Sales Tax Authorities on the other hand, companytend that the appellant is number entitled to take into companyputation at all his sales of oil outside the State and is also number entitled to deduct from his gross turnover the purchase price of companyra allocated to the oil sold to persons outside the State.

facts.text: Travancore-Cochin General Sales Tax Act, 1125 (Act XI of 1125 M.E.) amended by Travancore-Cochin General Sales Tax Amendment Act, 1951 adding s.26.

anchor.surface_text: the Travancore-Cochin General Sales Tax Act, 1125  Act XI of 1125 M.E.  and the Travancore-Cochin General Sales Tax Rules, 1950... The Act as originally enacted received the assent of the Rajpramukh on January 5, 1950. After the advent of the Constitution, however, the Act was amended by the Travancore-Cochin General Sales Tax  Amendment  Act, 1951

facts.text: Act received assent on January 5, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The Act as originally enacted received the assent of the Rajpramukh on January 5, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: there are three stages in the imposition of a tax. There is the declaration of liability, that is the part of the statute which determines what person in respect of what property are liable. Next, there is the assessment.

concepts.interpretation: 1. Declaration of liability first; no liability, no assessment; s.26 declares no liability for inter-state sales

anchor.surface_text: bringing within their ken not only the sales which were actually effected within the territory but also sales where adopting the nexus theory even one of the ingredients of sale was found to have taken place within the territory.

issues.text: We have to decide which of these calculations of the net turnover is correct having regard to the relevant provisions of the Act and the rules made there-under.

anchor.surface_text: The main controversy between the parties centres on the method of calculation of the net turnover. The appellant contends that in the calculation of such net turnover he is entitled to include the total value of the oil sold by him, viz., Rs. 6,76,719-0-11, irrespective of the fact whether these sales were effected inside the State or outside the State and deduct therefrom the total value of copra purchased by him from which the whole quantity of oil sold by him was manufactured, viz., Rs. 7,16,048-1-4. The resultant figure, according to him, represents the net assessable turnover on which the Sales Tax Authorities would be entitled to assess him to sales tax if the position in law was as it stood before the amendment of the Act by the Travancore-Cochin General Sales Tax (Amendment) Act, 1951.

issues.text: What, then, is the effect of this non-obstante provision?

anchor.surface_text: What, then, is the effect of this non-obstante provision ? This Court in Aswani Kumar Ghosh v. Arabinda Bose 1 made the following observations in connection with the non-obstante clause It should first be ascertained what the enacting part of the section provides on a fair construction

issues.text: Whether a distinction can be made between the inclusion of the value of inter-State sales of oil in the turnover of the dealer for the purpose of assessment and the levy of tax thereupon, allowing deduction of corresponding copra value under Rule 20.

Whether there is a broad distinction between exemptions from tax and non-imposition/non-liability to tax under section 26, such that inter-State sales are excluded from turnover calculation altogether.

arguments.claim: Appellant entitled to include total value of all oil sales (intra-state and inter-state) in gross turnover and deduct entire purchase price of copra converted into all such oil under Rule 20 read with Rule 7(1)(k), even after amendment by s.26.

anchor.surface_text: The main controversy between the parties centres on the method of calculation of the net turnover. The appellant contends that in the calculation of such net turnover he is entitled to include the total value of the oil sold by him, viz., Rs. 6,76,719-0-11, irrespective of the fact whether these sales were effected inside the State or outside the State and deduct therefrom the total value of copra purchased by him from which the whole quantity of oil sold by him was manufactured, viz., Rs. 7,16,048-1-4.

arguments.court_reasoning: s.26 non-obstante clause obliterates all provisions relating to imposition of tax on inter-state sales, excluding them from turnover; no applicability of r.20 deduction.

arguments.claim: s.26 prohibits only the levy/imposition of tax on inter-state sales, allowing their value to be included in turnover for assessment purposes with corresponding copra deduction under r.20.

anchor.surface_text: A distinction was sought to be made between the inclusion of the value of such oil in the turnover of the dealer for the purpose of assessment and the levy of tax thereupon. It was urged that the inclusion of such oil in the turnover for the purpose of assessment was quite distinct from the liability for tax which was the only thing prohibited by s. 26 of the Act

arguments.court_reasoning: No liability declared under s.26 for inter-state sales; stages of taxation require declaration of liability first before assessment; cannot include in turnover without liability.

arguments.claim: In fiscal statutes, tax liability arises only from strict letter of law, not spirit, substance, analogy or inference.

anchor.surface_text: The answer given by the learned counsel for the appellant to the above reasoning was that in fiscal statutes what you have got to look to is not the spirit of the statute but the letter of the law and if you could not bring a particular tax within the letter of the law, the subject could not be made liable for the same.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ld rise of the applicability of r. 7  1   k  and r. 20  2  at all to these cases. The amount for which the oil is sold in inter-State trade or company

arguments.court_reasoning: Principle accepted, but applied here: s.26 plainly excludes inter-state sales from Act's purview by its letter, so no tax and no inclusion/deduction.

arguments.claim: Appellant not entitled to include inter-state oil sales in turnover nor deduct purchase price of copra allocated to those sales, due to s.26 excluding them entirely.

anchor.surface_text: The Sales Tax Authorities on the other hand, contend that the appellant is not entitled to take into computation at all his sales of oil outside the State and is also not entitled to deduct from his gross turnover the purchase price of copra allocated to the oil sold to persons outside the State.

arguments.court_reasoning: s.26 non-obstante takes inter-state sales out of Act's purview; no inclusion in gross turnover, hence no r.20 deduction applicable.

arguments.claim: Definitions in s.2(j) and s.2(k) inapplicable to registered manufacturers for r.20; concession only to avoid double tax where both purchase tax on copra and sales tax on oil leviable; not for inter-state sales.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court decided against the appellant observing that the definitions given in s. 2 (j) and (k) of the Act applied only in the absence of anything repugnant in the subject or context, and on a perusal of the relevant provisions... it was of opinion that these definitions were clearly inapplicable... object is the avoidance of a double taxation... impossible to invoke the definition and say that the concession will be available... where only one and not both the taxes can be realized.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: sition on the observations of this Court in Messrs. Chatturam Horilram Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-Tax, Bihar and Orissa 1  As has been pointed out

arguments.court_reasoning: Relies on repugnancy to definitions, but s.26 non-obstante directly overrides without needing purposive limit on r.20; strict construction requires plain exclusion.

arguments.claim: Prior to s.26, provisions of Act and rules (ss.2(j),(k),3; rr.4,7(k),20) allow inclusion of all sales (intra/inter-state) in gross turnover and full deduction of copra value for registered manufacturer.

anchor.surface_text: The definition of sale contained in s. 2 (j) is wide enough to include, the sales of oil manufactured by the appellant whether these sales are effected inside the State or outside the State. The definition of turnover contained in s. 2 (k) of the Act also makes no distinction... Rule 4... Rule 7... cl. (k)... Rule 20... On a prima facie reading... would be entitled to include... and to deduct... irrespective of the fact whether such oil or cake was sold... inside the State or outside the State.

arguments.claim: s.26 is non-obstante clause that sets aside and obliterates provisions of Act (including charging s.3 and r.20) for sales covered by Art.286; such sales taken out of Act's purview entirely.
No distinction between inclusion in turnover for assessment and levy of tax; inter-state sales excluded from turnover as no liability under s.26.
Broad distinction: exemptions/rebates include sales in gross turnover then deduct; non-imposition/non-liability (s.26) excludes from gross/net turnover entirely as outside Act's purview.

Historical context: Sales tax acts pre-Constitution used nexus theory; post-Constitution, s.26-like provisions added as non-obstante to comply with Art.286 without amending definitions/charging sections.

anchor.surface_text: It may be noted at the outset that the main bulk of the Sales Tax Acts... before the Constitution... bringing within their ken not only the sales... nexus theory... When the Constitution... Art. 286 laid down restrictions... various expedients... adding... sections like s. 26... non-obstante provision...

arguments.claim: Provisions like in Assam/Hyderabad/Bombay explicitly exclude Art.286 sales from charging/definition/rules, but Travancore s.26 achieves same via non-obstante without amendment.

anchor.surface_text: A different expedient was adopted in the Assam Sales Tax Act... Hyderabad... r.5 of the Bombay... We are not called upon to express any opinion... What was done in the instant case... incorporation... non-obstante... The definition of sale was not amended nor was the charging section...

arguments.claim: Even if inter-state sales included for registration/returns purposes, does not affect non-liability under s.26/Art.286.

holdings.text: The appellant is not entitled to include the total value of all oil sold (intra-state and inter-state) in gross turnover and deduct the entire purchase price of copra under Rule 20; instead, inter-state sales are excluded from turnover and only copra value corresponding to intra-state sales is deductible.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.26 non-obstante clause overrides prior provisions including definitions, charging section, and Rule 20; inter-state sales taken out of Act's purview per Aswani Kumar Ghosh; prima facie rules allow full deduction pre-s.26 but s.26 excludes.

holdings.text: Section 26 is a non-obstante provision that sets aside inconsistent prior provisions of the Act, obliterating those relating to imposition of tax on sales covered by Art. 286, taking them out of the Act's purview.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Apply Aswani Kumar Ghosh: construe enacting part fairly, then non-obstante overrides inconsistencies; s.26 applies to all prior Act provisions for Art.286 sales.

holdings.text: There is no valid distinction between including inter-state sales value in turnover for assessment purposes and the levy of tax thereon; since s.26 prohibits liability to tax, such sales cannot be included in turnover at all.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Stages of taxation per Chatturam Horilram: declaration of liability first; no liability under s.26 means no assessment or turnover inclusion.

holdings.text: Exemptions/rebates require inclusion in gross turnover then deduction to reach net; non-imposition/non-liability under s.26 excludes sales from gross/net turnover entirely as outside Act's purview.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguish prima facie liable sales (exemptions deducted) from non-liable (excluded); s.26 enacts non-liability for Art.286 sales.

holdings.text: Provisions for dealer registration and sales tax returns do not affect the non-liability of inter-state sales to tax under s.26; such inclusion for administrative purposes does not create turnover for tax.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Administrative inclusions (registration/returns) separate from substantive tax liability excluded by s.26/Art.286.

holdings.text: Prior to s.26 amendment, the Act and Rules (ss.2(j),(k),3; rr.4,7(k),20) permitted inclusion of all sales (intra/inter-state) in gross turnover with full copra deduction for registered manufacturers.

anchor.surface_text: The definition of sale contained in s. 2 (j) is wide enough to include, the sales of oil manufactured by the appellant whether these sales are effected inside the State or outside the State. The definition of turnover contained in s. 2 (k) of the Act also makes no distinction...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of definitions, charging s.3, rr.4,7,20 shows no intra/inter-state distinction pre-amendment.

precedents.citation: Inland Revenue Commissioners v. Duke of Westminster 1

anchor.surface_text: Our attention was drawn in this connection to the observations of Lord Russell of Killowen in Inland Revenue Commissioners v. Duke of Westminster 1 I -confess that I view with disfavour the doctrine that in taxation cases the subject is to be taxed if in accordance

precedents.case_name: Inland Revenue Commissioners v Duke of Westminster
precedents.cited_proposition: In taxation cases, the subject is to be taxed only by the plain words of the statute, not by inference, analogy, or the spirit of the statute
precedents.cited_holding: I confess that I view with disfavour the doctrine that in taxation cases the subject is to be taxed if in accordance with a Courts view of what it considers the substance of the transaction, the Court thinks that the case falls within the contemplation or spirit of the statute. The subject is not taxable by inference or by analogy, but only by the plain words of a statute

anchor.surface_text: As Lord Cairns said many years ago in Partington v. The Attorney General 1 -As I understand the 1 1869 4 H.L. 100, 122. principle of all fiscal legislation it is this if the person sought to be taxed comes within the letter of the law he must be taxed, however great the

precedents.cited_proposition: If the person sought to be taxed comes within the letter of the law he must be taxed; if not, he is free however apparently within the spirit
precedents.cited_holding: As I understand the principle of all fiscal legislation it is this if the person sought to be taxed comes within the letter of the law he must be taxed, however great the hardship may appear to the judicial mind to be. On the other hand, if the Crown... cannot bring the subject within the letter of the law, the subject is free

precedents.citation: Bank of Chettinad v. Income Tax Commissioner 1

anchor.surface_text: The passage was quoted with approval by the Privy Council in the Bank of Chettinad v. Income Tax Commissioner 1 and the Privy Council registered its protest against the suggestion that in revenue cases the substance of the matter may be regarded as distinguished from the strict legal position.

precedents.case_name: Bank of Chettinad v Income Tax Commissioner
precedents.cited_proposition: Quoted with approval the principle of strict letter of the law in fiscal statutes; protest against regarding substance over strict legal position

precedents.citation: F. L. Smidth Co. v. F. Greenwood 2

anchor.surface_text: See also F. L. Smidth Co. v. F. Greenwood 2 . It is no doubt true that in construing fiscal statutes and in determining the liability of a subject to tax one must have regard to the strict letter of the law and not merely to the spirit of the statute or the substance of the law.

precedents.case_name: F L Smidth & Co v F Greenwood
precedents.cited_proposition: Support for strict construction of fiscal statutes

precedents.citation: Aswani Kumar Ghosh v. Arabinda Bose 1

anchor.surface_text: This Court in Aswani Kumar Ghosh v. Arabinda Bose 1 made the following observations in connection with the non-obstante clause It should first be ascertained what the enacting part of the section provides on a fair construction of the words used according to their natural

precedents.case_name: Aswini Kumar Ghosh v Arabinda Bose
precedents.cited_proposition: Construction of non-obstante clause: first ascertain enacting part, then non-obstante sets aside inconsistent prior law
precedents.cited_holding: It should first be ascertained what the enacting part of the section provides on a fair construction of the words used according to their natural and ordinary meaning, and the non-obstante clause is to be understood as operating to set aside as no longer valid anything contained in relevant existing laws which is inconsistent with the new enactment.

precedents.citation: Messrs. Chatturam Horilram Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-Tax, Bihar and Orissa 1

anchor.surface_text: Reliance was placed in support of this position on the observations of this Court in Messrs. Chatturam Horilram Ltd. v. anchor.surface_text: quoting from the judgment of Lord Dunedin in Whitney v. Commissioners of Inland Revenue 1 there are three stages in the imposition of a tax. There is the declaration of liability, that is the part of the statute which determines what person in respect of what property are liable.

precedents.case_name: Whitney v Commissioners of Inland Revenue
precedents.cited_proposition: Three stages in imposition of tax: declaration of liability, assessment, methods of recovery
precedents.cited_holding: there are three stages in the imposition of a tax. There is the declaration of liability... Next, there is the assessment. Liability does not depend on assessment... Lastly, come the methods of recovery
